sentences.english: Don’t become cynical, but verify everything you can. The lesson learned: make sure you know who it is you’re dealing with and what their motives may be.
sentences.chinese: 不要憤世嫉俗，但是近你所能覈實一切。

sentences.english: Your inner cynic can accelerate your learning
sentences.chinese: 內心的憤世嫉俗可以加速你的學習。

sentences.english: Some women who answered the questions were found to be snikly hostel cynically hostile, or highly untrusting of others.
sentences.chinese: 一些回答問題的婦女憤世嫉俗或者極度不相信他人。

sentences.english: Your inner cynic can protect you and alert you to BS
sentences.chinese: 內心的憤世嫉俗可以保護你，並提醒你的無知。

sentences.english: Your inner cynic can help you to observe reality more accurately
sentences.chinese: 內心的憤世嫉俗可以幫助你更仔細的觀察到真相。

sentences.english: Some women whoansweranswered the questions were found to besynicallyhostlecynicallyhostile, or highly untrusting of others.
sentences.chinese: 受調查的一些女性憤世嫉俗或非常不信任他人。

sentences.english: Loss has not embittered him or made him cynical.
sentences.chinese: 然而控制權的喪失並未使他痛苦不堪或憤世嫉俗。

sentences.english: Just because I am not a misanthrope?
sentences.chinese: 難道僅因爲我確非憤世嫉俗之輩？

sentences.english: Your inner cynic can help you to focus your problem-solving efforts
sentences.chinese: 內心的憤世嫉俗可以幫助你集中精力解決問題。

sentences.english: Therefore he earned the fame of being a misanthrope.
sentences.chinese: 因此他獲得了憤世嫉俗者的名聲。

sentences.english: If people are irrational in their attitudes to reality, they may become cynical.
sentences.chinese: 如果人們對現實的態度失去理性就會變得憤世嫉俗。

sentences.english: Yes, I'm both a romantic and a cynic.
sentences.chinese: 是的，我是既浪漫又憤世嫉俗的。

sentences.english: Why are you always so cynical?
sentences.chinese: 爲什麼你如此的憤世嫉俗？

sentences.english: You might think she’d be cynical by now.
sentences.chinese: 你也許會認爲她現在一定憤世嫉俗。

definition: lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
frigid irony and scorching satire (idiom); to mock and ridicule
to rebel against orthodoxy/to depart from established practices
to obstinately persist in going about things the wrong way (idiom)
to force someone to do something
when things reach an extreme, they can only move in the opposite direction (idiom)
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
not one good point/everything about it is wrong
